msgSnippet: Perhaps you could break bigger tests into smaller tests and make the body of each test self-describing ? public void
messageBody:
Perhaps you could break bigger tests into smaller tests and make the
body of each test self-describing ?

public void testInsertTooLargeValueIntoTableIfSuchAndSuch(){
suchAndSuch.enable(true);
table.insertValue(LARGE_VALUE);
assertTrue("Did this occur ?", thisOccurred);
}

public void testInsertTooLargeValueIntoTableIfNotSuchAndSuch(){
suchAndSuch.enable(false);
table.insertValue(LARGE_VALUE);
assertTrue("Did other occur ?", otherOccurred);
}


I have not found too many upper-management-type people who are
interested in the details of my unit tests .... but you can communicate
a lot in system-level/acceptance tests that take the place of a spec
even to people who don't know Java.


For example :

public class CoverageSmokeTest extends AgitationTestCase {

public void test100PercentCoverage() throws Exception {
agitate(SimpleMath.class);

getClassResult(SimpleMath.class).assertPercentageCovered(100);

CoverageHarness coverage = getCoverageResults(SimpleMath.class);
coverage.assertAllPointsCovered();
}

}

If I were to write this test in-line, it would be several hundred lines
long. But, with a little intention-revealing refactoring, I can convey
that after you *agitate SimpleMath.class you should get 100% coverage. I
get the added bonus that most of the extracted methods and classes end
up in a test harness that is re-usable.


I have found that this technique is rarely necessary for unit tests
because the tests are so short anyway. But for higher level tests where
there is typically a lot of re-use it is very valuable.

Kevin

* 'agitate' is what our product does - so even if /you/ don't know what
that means (yet) our upper-management does.
